CLWA uses chlorine (CAS# 7782-50-5) at the RVWTP in quantities large enough to trigger the USEPA RMP and CalARP.  The USEPA RMP threshold quantity for chlorine is 2,500 pounds.  The CalARP threshold quantity for chlorine is 100 pounds.  The maximum quantity currently present is 32 @ 1-ton cylinders (64,000 pounds) of chlorine.  Chlorine is transported to the facility by truck and stored onsite in 1-ton cylinders.

The CLWA RVWTP also is subject to OSHA PSM regulations for all equipment and operations associated with chlorine storage and disinfection systems. The threshold quantity under PSM for chlorine is 1,500 pounds.

Accidental Releases during Past Five Years

The CLWA Rio Vista Water Treatment Plant has not had any releases during the past five years that resulted in any injuries, off-site evacuations, or property damage.

Process Safety Management Accident Prevention Program

The CLWA Rio Vista Water Treatment Plant is subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations for all equipment and operations associated with its chlorine system. The CLWA's PSM programs include the following activities to minimize the potential for an accidental release:

* Review of the design of all equipment and controls for the chlorine system to establish they are properly designed and installed.

* Updating of standard operating procedures to include specific information on safety procedures. All procedures must be reviewed and are certified annually.

* Initial safety training and 3-year refresher training for all operators and maintenance staff.

* Procedures to provide all contractors with information on chemical safety training.

* Regular inspection of all equipment, monitoring systems and controls, with documentation of all inspections.

Introduction

The previous RMP Plans for the chlorine disinfection system at the CLWA's Rio Vista Water Treatment Plant were submitted on June 16, 1999, June 16, 2004 and December 18, 2008.  Between 2009 and June 2011, the Rio Vista Water Treatment Plant was expanded.  The expansion project included the the construction of a new chlorine building and an increase in the maximum inventory of chlorine from 16 to 32 one-ton cylinders.

Facility Description

The CLWA RVWTP is located at 27234 Bouquet Canyon Road in Santa Clarita, California. RVWTP is on a property covering 65 acres. RVWTP is provided State Project water stored in Castaic Lake. The plant is currently capable of treating 60 million gallons per day (mgd) of water with an additional future capacity of 120 mgd.  

Raw water is first delivered to the pre-ozone contactor where ozone is applied for pre-oxidation and pre-disinfection. Ozonated water then enters the rapid mix structure where coagulants are added. The water is then fed to up-flow clarifiers, and then to a gravity filtration system. In the final stage, filtered water is disinfected with chlorine, monitored for chlorine residual, dosed with ammonia to create chloramines and released to CLWA's transmission system for distribution.

Potentially hazardous chemicals stored and used onsite or for which storage is available include chlorine, aqueous ammonia (19%), hydrogen peroxide, diesel fuel, liquefied oxygen, and sodium hydroxide and polymer. Liquid chlorine, used for disinfection of water, is stored in one-ton cylinders. The maximum quantity of chlorine currently stored at the plant is currently 32 cylinders (64,000 pounds). Chlorine is present in quantities above the RMP threshold. The other chemicals are either addressed in a separate RMP Plans required by the State of California(i.e. aqueous ammonia), not covered under the RMP program, or are present in quantities below the thresholds.

Emergency Response Procedures

CLWA Rio Vista Water Treatment Plant has prepared a California Consolidated Contingency Plan (CCCP) to provide step-by-step procedures for emergency response in the unlikely event of an accidental release. The Safety Coordinator maintains the CCCP. The key elements of CLWA's emergency preparedness program are as follows:

* The plant uses a combination of audible alarms and a plant loudspeaker system to alert the staff of a potential accident and to conduct in-plant communications.

* In the event of a large release, the facility would immediately contact the Los Angeles County Fire Department and evacuate to designated staging areas.

* In the event of an uncontroled chlorine release in the chlorine building, the scrubber system would activiate and remove/neutralize chlorine gas in the chlorine building. 

CLWA's Recent Steps to Improve Safety

Based on CLWA's dedication to process safety and the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) review that was conducted in April 2011, CLWA has integrated the following components and procedures into the chlorine disinfection system to reduce the likelihood or severity of potential chlorine releases:
* A chlorine gas detection system
* An emergency chlorine shutoff system that will automatically activate if a chlorine gas leak i

s detected. 
* A chlorine gas scrubber that will start and operate to remove and neutralize chlorine gas that is in the Chlorine Building. 
* Extensive operator training
* Periodic process hazard review updates for the chlorination system
